journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of consulting and clinical psychology

title-group.article-title: Examining Racial and Ethnic Differences in Youth Psychotherapy Treatment Engagement and Outcomes

fn.p: Author Contributions: Kara Johansen contributed through conceptualization of the manuscript, project administration by coordinating this secondary analysis manuscript, and writing in the original draft and in revisions. Dr. Indrani Saran contributed through formal analysis as the statistician, visualization (e.g., in tables), and writing in the original draft and in revisions. Dr. Evelyn Cho contributed through writing in the original draft and writing in revisions. Dr. John Weisz contributed through funding acquisition, investigation, and methodology for the original RCT analyzed, as well as writing in the original draft and revisions. Dr. Maggi Price is the senior author on this manuscript; she contributed through conceptualization of the manuscript, supervision of the writing team, and writing in the original draft and writing in revisions.

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence regarding this article should be sent to Maggi Price at maggi.price@bc.edu or to 74 Cornwall St., Jamaica Plain, MA 02130.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: Research has identified racial/ethnic disparities in mental health treatment engagement and there have been recent calls to examine effects of mental health treatment engagement on clinical outcomes among youth of Color. This study aimed to examine racial/ethnic differences in (1) behavioral and attitudinal engagement, (2) treatment effectiveness, and (3) the associations between engagement and treatment effectiveness.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: N=200 youth (ages 7–15; 33% White, 28% Black, 25% Hispanic/Latinx, and 14% Multiracial; 52% male) and their N=200 parents participated in a randomized controlled trial testing the effectiveness of a transdiagnostic psychotherapy for common youth emotional and behavioral problems. Youth and parents reported internalizing and externalizing symptoms and treatment engagement (e.g., behavioral and attitudinal). Multilevel regression models examined variations in youth symptom trajectories by racial/ethnic group.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: While all racial/ethnic groups showed comparable attitudinal engagement scores, Black and Latinx youth attended significantly fewer sessions than White and Multiracial youth (8–9 versus 13). However, youth in all racial/ethnic groups showed significant, and similar, improvements in treatment outcomes.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Black and Latinx youth attended fewer sessions than White youth, but their clinical outcomes were similar to those of White youth. Future research should examine the meaning and implications of session attendance in relation to outcomes in youth of Color.

abstract.title: Public Health Significance:
abstract.p: This study showed that Black and Latinx youth derive comparable benefits from transdiagnostic treatment despite attending fewer sessions than their White counterparts. The findings emphasize the need for a shift toward personalized and efficient mental health interventions for youth of Color.
